Triangles are equilateral because .

The condition simply means that (assume is on the same side of as ) lies on the arc which doesn't contain , so is the internal bisector of because is the midpoint of the arc (without the condition, would be the external bisector). This means that lies on the bisector of .

On the other hand, we have and because they're both , so is the reflection of in the midpoint of . This means , and since and lies on the internal bisector of , it means that is the incenter (the only other position on from which is seen under an angle of is , and it's clear that ).

4

orl
view topic
Click for solution
A quick angle chase reveals that is cyclic, meaning that we can forget about the 's: we're looking for the locus of the circumcenter of .

Since are constant angles, it means that the triangles are all similar, and this means that the triangles are all similar, where is the circumcenter of . This means that the locus of is the image of through the spiral similarity of center which turns into . In other words, this locus is a circle, Q.E.D.

Comment: it can be shown fairly easily now, by choosing particular positions of , the the circle is, in fact, the circumcircle of , where is the center of .

5
For any set of five points in the plane, no three of which are collinear, let and denote the greatest and smallest areas, respectively, of triangles determined by three points from . What is the minimum possible value of ?
orl
view topic
Click for solution
I think it's achieved for the regular pentagon, so it's .

First of all, let's notice that if it's not a convex pentagon, then we have a point inside a triangle, so that point is inside a triangle formed by the centroid and two vertices of the triangle, so the ratio would be at least . This means that the pentagons which reach the minimal value are convex.

Furthermore, it's easy to see that, since the pentagon is convex, the triangle with the minimal area is formed by three consecutive vertices, while the one with the largest area is formed by three vertices which are not consecutive.

Assume our pentagon is , and the triangle with minimal area is . Since we can apply an affine transformation which maps to three consecutive vertices of a regular pentagon and this transformation preserves the ratios of areas, we may assume there is a regular pentagon . Take s.t. . Since , and given the convexity of , at least one of lies inside (just draw a picture to see why). Assume it's . We can move along lines parallel to s.t. the area of increases, and this time lie on the union of the two segments math=inline]$XC'$[/math, math=inline]$XD'$[/math. It's easy now to see that we can enlarge the area of even more by moving s.t. they reach positions , but this means that the initial area of was smaller that that of , and this is a contradiction, so the minimal ratio is reached for regular pentagons.

I know the argument is a bit murky, but it's not that hard to see why it works if you draw a picture.
grobber

I don't like this solution, but I couldn't find a better one this late at night (or this early in the morning; it's 4:15 AM here ).

Let , and let be the antipode of on . Let be the touch points between and respectively.

The line is parallel to and is cut into two equal parts by , so . This means that the quadrilateral is harmonic, so the tangents to through meet on . On the other hand, the tangents to through the points meet on , so is also harmonic, meaning that the tangents to through meet on .

From these it follows that are concurrent. If , it's well-known that , and since , it means that lies on an Apollonius circle, so is the bisector of .

From here the conclusion follows, because if , we get , so there's a homothety of center which maps to the circumcircle of .

We take . What follows is a standard argument: given a solution with , we show that we can find a solution with .

Start with (this is a solution of the equation). Let be the property and let be the property . Furthermore, let be . It’s clear that hold.

Let’s now take . holds because we already know from , and because otherwise we would have , which is false. is equally easy to check. Let’s now prove : because of the definition of , , which is true because , and , which is true because . We have thus shown that hold, and, in particular, we can define , and so on. We use the exact same arguments to prove that are true, so we can define .

On the other hand, a simple computation reveals that if is a solution, then so is , so we have found infinitely many solutions (that’s because the inequalities in become strict for , due to ).

Combinatorics
1
Let be a positive integer. Each point in the plane, where and are non-negative integers with , is coloured red or blue, subject to the following condition: if a point is red, then so are all points with and . Let be the number of ways to choose blue points with distinct -coordinates, and let be the number of ways to choose blue points with distinct -coordinates. Prove that .
orl
view topic
Click for solution
This was actually in the contest, wasn't it?

It's kind of hard to put into words. The red points consists of a series of columns of decreasing height (I mean decreasing starting from left to right, and I don't mean strictly decreasing). The blue points consist of the completion of the red columns up to the border of the triangle having vertices . At the same time, the blue and red sets can also be regarded as rows instead of columns.

is simply the product of the lengths of all blue columns, while is the product of the lengths of all blue rows. If we show that the same numbers, with the same multiplicities, appear in the collections of a) blue column lengths and b) blue row lengths, then we are clearly done. Call this assertion .

The blue set can be regarded as the union of some maximal right triangles with the legs parallel to the axes of the plane (maximal in the sense that they aren't part of any other similar right triangles). The triangles are obtained as follows: from a point on the diagonal go down as far as you can without taking any red points. Now go to the right until you meet the diagonal again. The maximal triangles of this set are the ones we're looking for.

We can now prove the assertion by induction on .

If there are points on the diagonal which are red, then it's easy to see that the number of blue columns of length is equal to the number of blue rows of length , and we can look at the picture as the union of some smaller pictures (for smaller 's), by breaking the diagonal where it has red points. We use the induction hypothesis on these smaller pictures.

On the other hand, if no points on are red, then we can look at the points strictly below the diagonal , and use the induction hypothesis on these. After we append the diagonal all lengths (of blue columns and rows) increase by , so we have shown what we wanted: the number of blue columns of length is the same as the number of blue rows of length for all .

Watch out: I might have reversed "red" and "blue" in some places.
grobber
view topic

When it is possible, what is the minimum number of trominos needed?

This discussion might give some insight.

Let's work in , for simplicity. In this setting, we have .

A mere adaptation of the solution posted there by alekk: construct a graph with vertices labeled . We draw a directed edge from to iff or (we allow loops, i.e. edges like ). The edge represents the residue or , according to the situation. Each residue is represented by exactly one edge, so the problem is reduced to proving that the graph we have described is Eulerian, which is clear because each vertex has outgoing edges and incoming edges.

IMO Shortlist 2001
Geometry
1
Let be the center of the square inscribed in acute triangle with two vertices of the square on side . Thus one of the two remaining vertices of the square is on side and the other is on . Points are defined in a similar way for inscribed squares with two vertices on sides and , respectively. Prove that lines are concurrent.
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Here is my solution:

Let X, Y, Z be the centers of the squares BCTU, CAVW, ABSR constructed on the segments BC, CA, AB and pointing into the exterior of triangle ABC. The square inscribed in triangle ABC with two vertices on BC, one on AB and one on AC is homothetic to the square constructed on the segment BC into the exterior of triangle ABC, the center of homothety being A; hence, the centers and X of these two squares are collinear with A, i. e. the line coincides with the line AX. Similarly, the line coincides with BY, and the line coincides with CZ. Hence, instead of proving that the lines , , concur, it will be enough to show that the lines AX, BY, CZ concur.

Well, why do the lines AX, BY, CZ concur? There are several proofs of this fact; here is the most elementary of them: I will show that the lines AX, BY, CZ are perpendicular to the lines YZ, ZX, XY, respectively; then, it will follow that AX, BY, CZ are the altitudes of triangle XYZ and hence concur.

Why are the lines AX, BY, CZ perpendicular to YZ, ZX, XY?

Well, the spiral dilatation with center B, rotation angle 45 and dilatation factor maps C to T and Z to A. Hence, the segment TA is the image of the segment CZ, so that

< (CZ; TA) = 45

(where < (k; l) denotes the directed angle between two lines k and l).

The spiral dilatation with center C, rotation angle 45 and dilatation factor maps T to X and A to Y. Hence, the segment XY is the image of the segment TA, so that

< (TA; XY) = 45,

and < (CZ; XY) = < (CZ; TA) + < (TA; XY) = 45 + 45 = 90, so that CZ is perpendicular to XY. Similarly, AX is perpendicular to YZ and BY is perpendicular to ZX, and we are done.

[By the way, the same approach using spiral dilatations shows that AX = YZ, BY = ZX and CZ = XY.]

Darij
darij grinberg

The minimum of the expression is achieved when P coincides with the centroid G of triangle ABC, and this minimum equals .

Proof. Using vectors and their scalar products, we have for any three points U, V and W, and equality holds if and only if the point W lies on the ray UV. Thus,

,

with equality holding if and only if the point G lies on the ray AP, on the ray BP and on the ray CP simultaneously, i. e. if and only if the point P coincides with the point G.

Now,



.

Now, since the point G is the centroid of triangle ABC, we have , and thus


.

After the well-known formula for the median lengths in a triangle, the length of the median of triangle ABC issuing from the vertex A satisfies the equation . Since the point G is the centroid of triangle ABC and thus divides all medians in the ratio 2 : 1, we have , and thus

.

Similarly,

;
,

and thus

.

Hence, we have

.

Now, since

,

it follows that

,

with equality if and only if the point P coincides with the point G. In other words, the minimum of the expression is achieved for P = G and equals . Proof complete.

Click for solution
You are right, Grobber's solution is incorrect. He probably got confused by the asymmetric notations (this also happened to me when I saw the problem first). However, the problem is still quite easy:

In the following, will mean the (non-directed) area of a triangle .

Let d be the circle with center D and radius DA = DC. This circle d clearly passes through the points A and C. Similarly, we have a circle e with center E and radius EA = EB, which passes through the points A and B, and a circle f with center F and radius FB = FC, which passes through the points B and C.

Let the two circles d and e intersect at a point S (apart from A). In the circle e, the angle < BEA is the central angle of the chord AB, while the angle < ASB is the obtuse chordal angle over this chord; hence, . Comparing this with , we get < ABC = 180° - < ASB, so that < ASB = 180° - < ABC. Similarly, we find < ASC = 180° - < BAC, since the point S lies on the circle d. Hence,

< BSC = 360° - < ASB - < ASC = 360° - (180° - < ABC) - (180° - < BAC)
= < ABC + < BAC = 180° - < ACB (by the sum of angles in triangle ABC).

Thus, < ACB = 180° - < BSC. Hence, becomes . Now, since the points B and C lie on the circle f, and the angle < CFB is the central angle of the chord BC in this circle, this equation yields that < BSC is the obtuse chordal angle over the chord BC in this circle f; thus, the point S lies on the circle f.

Hence, the point S lies on all three circles d, e, f. The points B and S, being the two common points of the circles e and f, must be symmetric to each other with respect to the line EF joining the centers E and F of these circles; hence, the triangles BEF and SEF are congruent, so that | BEF | = | SEF |.

The two triangles DD'E and BD'E have a common altitude from the vertex E; thus, their areas are proportional to their bases DD' and BD'. In other words, . In other words, . Similarly, . Hence,



,

so that

.

Hence,

.

Similarly,

;
.

Thus,


.

And the problem is solved.

Darij
darij grinberg

It's well-known that has roots in . Assume what we're trying to prove doesn't hold. In each pair there's at least a root of , so there are at least roots of among the first residues . If is a root of , then so is (in , of course), so there are at least other roots of among the last residues .

This means that the roots of lie in the intervals and . However, we can clearly find roots which are not in these intervals, for example the product of two roots chosen from the pairs . Their product is and . For this product is outside the two intervals mentioned above, and for we can check it manually (take ).

Since , we can use Cesaro-Stolz to prove .

It looks rather nasty. Does it work?

view topic
Click for solution
I think it's .

can be achieved by taking 's, followed by 's, followed by 's.

Let's now prove that it's the maximum we can achieve. Break the sequence into maximal subsequences which are also arthimetic progressions of common difference . Two such progressions don't intersect, so they don't interfere (we can't have -element progressions with elements from two different such subsequences). Assume we have such a subsequence . This contributes to , so we can change the first numbers into the same number (say ), then the next numbers into , and the remeining numbers into . This new sey contributes to , and this is clearly . We do this for all subsequences of the form considered above, until we get, in the end, some 's, some 's, and some 's.

Furthermore, if we have followed by (or followed by or ), we can interchange these two and we increase , so after performing all operations of this sort we get . In this case , with , and after applying we find , Q.E.D.

3
Define a -clique to be a set of people such that every pair of them are acquainted with each other. At a certain party, every pair of 3-cliques has at least one person in common, and there are no 5-cliques. Prove that there are two or fewer people at the party whose departure leaves no 3-clique remaining.
orl
view topic
4
A set of three nonnegative integers with is called historic if . Show that the set of all nonnegative integers can be written as the union of pairwise disjoint historic sets.
orl
view topic
5
Find all finite sequences such that for every , , equals the number of times appears in the sequence.
orl
view topic
6
For a positive integer define a sequence of zeros and ones to be balanced if it contains zeros and ones. Two balanced sequences and are neighbors if you can move one of the symbols of to another position to form . For instance, when , the balanced sequences and are neighbors because the third (or fourth) zero in the first sequence can be moved to the first or second position to form the second sequence. Prove that there is a set of at most balanced sequences such that every balanced sequence is equal to or is a neighbor of at least one sequence in .
orl
view topic
7
A pile of pebbles is placed in a vertical column. This configuration is modified according to the following rules. A pebble can be moved if it is at the top of a column which contains at least two more pebbles than the column immediately to its right. (If there are no pebbles to the right, think of this as a column with 0 pebbles.) At each stage, choose a pebble from among those that can be moved (if there are any) and place it at the top of the column to its right. If no pebbles can be moved, the configuration is called a final configuration. For each , show that, no matter what choices are made at each stage, the final configuration obtained is unique. Describe that configuration in terms of .

IMO ShortList 2001, combinatorics problem 7, alternative
orl
view topic
Click for solution
1) First of all, we need to show that we do eventually have to stop. This is clear because each time we move a pebble goes to the right, and we can't go arbitrarily far to the right, because each pebble (except for those on the first column) has another pebble immediately to its left, so we would need infinitely many pebbles. This shows that there always is a final configuration.

2) Another thing we notice is that a final configuration consists of columns of decreasing length (from left to right).

This is because before and after each move, this property is clearly conserved. Moreover, the difference between a column and its right neighbour is or , because otherwise we would be able to continue moving the pebbles.

3) In a final configuration we can't have three consecutive columns of equal lengths.

This is true because if we look at the last move performed on one of the three columns, then we see that no matter how we make that move, before we make it we need two consecutive columns s.t. the one on the left has fewer pebbles than the one on the right, and this is impossible. In fact, this shows that we never have three equal consecutive columns (not just in final configurations).

4) In a final configuration we can't have two different pairs of equal consecutive columns.

Consider two such pairs and , s.t. is to the right of , which don't have any other such pairs between them. Since this is a final config, the columns between and inclusive form a decreasing arithmetic progression with common difference . We can now retrace the steps until we get two pairs of equal columns which are adjacent and which differ in length by , and this is clearly impossible (consider, for example, ; no matter how we try to obtain this, we can't avoid either two consecutive solumns s.t. the one on the left is shorter, or three equal consecutive columns, and we have examined these situations before).

These conditions show that the final configuration is unique, because each has only one decomposition as a sum of different numbers except, maybe, for a pair, and this decomposition is obtained as follows: assume we have . Then we write as . These are also the lengths of the columns.
grobber
view topic
8
Twenty-one girls and twenty-one boys took part in a mathematical competition. It turned out that each contestant solved at most six problems, and for each pair of a girl and a boy, there was at least one problem that was solved by both the girl and the boy. Show that there is a problem that was solved by at least three girls and at least three boys.
orl

3
Let be the circumcenter and the orthocenter of an acute triangle . Show that there exist points , , and on sides , , and respectively such that and the lines , , and are concurrent.
orl
view topic
Click for solution
We know that the orthocenter reflects over the sides of the triangle on the circumcircle. Therefore the minimal distance equals . Obviously we can achieve this on all sides, so we assume that are the intersection points between the reflections of across respectively. All we have to prove is that , and are concurrent.

In order to do that we need the ratios , and , and then we can apply Ceva's theorem.

We know that the triangle is acute, so , therefore . In particular this means that . Since and , we have that and .

By the Sine theorem in the triangles and , we get


Using the similar relationships for and we get that those three fractions multiply up to 1, and thus by Ceva's, the lines and are concurrent.

A member of the audience draws two cards from two different boxes and announces the sum of numbers on those cards. Given this information, the magician locates the box from which no card has been drawn.

How many ways are there to put the cards in the three boxes so that the trick works?

Geometry
1
Let ABC be a triangle and be an interior point. Prove that

orl
view topic
Click for solution
This is one problem I had in one TST in 2000. Solution:

Consider the following lemma: let be a triangle and let be a point on the side such that . Then the following inequality takes place:



If let us consider the point on the segment such that .
We have and thus , because is the largest side the triangle .
But , so we are done.

If we have and thus , because is the largest side the triangle .


Back to the problem, we notice that at least two of the angles , , are larger than . Indeed, if two of them are less than , since their sum is , one of them would be larger than which is an obvious contradiction.

So, let us suppose WLOG that and . Also consider . We apply the lemma for the triangles and and we obtain


From (1) and (2), by addition, we obtain
which solves our problem.

Also there is the official solution, much complicated which I will post later.
Valentin Vornicu
view topic
2
A circle is called a separator for a set of five points in a plane if it passes through three of these points, it contains a fourth point inside and the fifth point is outside the circle. Prove that every set of five points such that no three are collinear and no four are concyclic has exactly four separators.
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Cute problem .

First of all, let's observe that for any , there is a separator through . This is because there are three circles through , and there is at most one circle containing the other two points and at most one leaving the other two points outside, so there is at least one which is a separator. This, in turn, means that there are at least separators because if there are , then these have at most chords with endpoints , but there are segments , a contradiction.

Another observation: through a point (let's call it ) there are or separators: after the inversion of pole the quadrilateral (where, in general, is the image of ) is either convex or concave. A separator is the preimage of a line which separates the other two images of points, and there are two such lines (the diagonals) if is convex, and three (concurrent) if is concave. From this we have also obtained the fact that if through there are separators, then there is an s.t. all the three separators also pass through .

Assume now that through each point there are separators. It's easy to get a contradiction based only on the fact that we can't find at least subsets of s.t. each point belongs to exactly two sets.

This means that there is at least a pair (call it ) of points with separators each. Then are separators, and it's pretty clear that is also a separator. Any attempt to add another separator will cause one of to have more than separators passing through it, and this is a contradiction.

Sorry if it appears long and boring..
grobber
view topic

I remember posting this a long time ago .

Consider the inversion wrt the incircle. It invariates the incircle and , so it turns into , for any . At the same time, if the incircle touches in , then the inversion turns into the midpoint of and the like, so are the midpoints of respectively, meaning that the circumcircle of is the nine-point circle of , thus having half its circumradius, which is the inradius of .
grobber
view topic
6
Two circles and touch internally the circle in M and N and the center of is on . The common chord of the circles and intersects in and . and intersects in and . Prove that is tangent to .
orl
view topic
Click for solution
{U,V} = o1^o2; E=AN^o2; F=BN^o2;p=DF^CE ; X = centre(o1); Y = centre(o2).
AC*AM = AV*AU = AE*AN ==> MNEC cyclic;
<ACE = <ANM = <ABM = <CDM ==> CE tangent to o1;
<AEC = <AMN = <ABN = <EFN ==> EC tangent to o2;
G= o2^XY, H = foot(Y) on CX; YH//CE ==> XH = r1 – r2 = XG ==> CXG == YXH ==> <CGX = 90°
XY symmetry axes of CD and EF ==> <DGX = 90°.
sprmnt21
view topic
7
The point is inside the convex quadrilateral , such that



Prove that and
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Let A' = DM^BC, from <CMD = <MCB+<MAB it follows that ABA'M is ciclyc.
Let C' = BM^AD, from <AMB = <MAD+<MCD it follows that DMCC' is ciclyc.

As supplementary of the same angle, it holds that <DMA = <CBA. From collinearity problem we have that <ACB = <DAM. Then DM/AM = AB/BC and finally DM/CM=AB/BC.

As both supplementary of the equal angles <C'MC = <C'DC, it holds <BMC = <ADC. Furthermore, see again collinearity problem, <MCB = <MCA+<ACB = <MAC+<DAM = <DAC. Then BM/MC=CD/AD or BM/MA=CD/AD.
sprmnt21
view topic

orl
view topic
Click for solution

3
A biologist watches a chameleon. The chameleon catches flies and rests after each catch. The biologist notices that:
  1. the first fly is caught after a resting period of one minute;
  2. the resting period before catching the fly is the same as the resting period before catching the fly and one minute shorter than the resting period before catching the fly;
  3. when the chameleon stops resting, he catches a fly instantly.

  1. How many flies were caught by the chameleon before his first resting period of minutes in a row?
  2. After how many minutes will the chameleon catch his fly?
  3. How many flies were caught by the chameleon after 1999 minutes have passed?

6
Suppose that every integer has been given one of the colours red, blue, green or yellow. Let and be odd integers so that . Show that there are two integers of the same colour whose difference has one of the following values: or .
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Let's assume (clearly, we can do this, since if what we want to prove doesn't hold, then it doesn't hold if we replace with and/or with ). Let's work with non-negative integers only.

The negation of what we want to prove states that there is a set s.t. are mutually disjoint, and their union is . This means that, working with formal power series, . Assume now that . We have .

When we divide by we have to get a series whose only coefficients are and , and this will yield the contradiction: our series contains , because . There must be a s.t. (the interval is open because the endpoints are even, but is odd). However, there is an s.t. , and this means that if our power series has no negative terms (to get rid of , which does not appear in ), when multiplied by contains , but doesn't have this term, so we have a contradiction.

A quick angle chase reveals , so the triangles are, in fact, congruent, meaning that is a parallelogram. This, however, means that the triangles are similar (because they have three pairs of perpendicular sides), so , Q.E.D.

Here's a sketch (I don't want to go into all the details, but I will if you really want me to ).

Try to show that when are fixed, moves on the hyperbola having as its center and as one of its vertices, which has eccentricity . To be precise, lies on the branch of this hyperbola which doesn't pass through .

also lies on this ellipse, being the "antipode" of . Let be the symmetric of wrt . This means that is also on the hyperbola, on the other branch (the branch which doesn't contain ). From this condition we find that in the triangle , if is the point where the perp bisector of cuts , then . Let be the point where the bisector of cuts . We then get . At the same time, from , we find to be the bisector of .

Now show that . What interests us is that . A quick angle chase gives what we want.

I'm sure there's a simpler solution, but I can't see anything right now, sorry.

It's still nice to have a solution posted .

Let be the point on the circle s.t. . We see that the four lines for a harmonic quadruple, so their intersections with the circle (other than ) for a harmonic quadrilateral, i.e. the quadrilateral is harmonic. This means that the tangents from to the circle meet on the diagonal , so are collinear. We will keep this in mind in what follows.

Since and , we find the triangles to be similar. At the same time, the triangles are similar, so are similar. What we have to prove is now reduced to a simple angle chase: , and that's it.

2
Determine all pairs of real numbers such that for all positive integers . (Note that denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to .)
orl
view topic
Click for solution
First of all, notice that one of the numbers is , then we have a solution, no matter what the other number is, so let's assume that they're both non-.

Another thing worth noticing is that the condition is equivalent to . Clearly, from this condition we get .

Let's consider the case when both our numbers are irrational. We have . is dense in , so if we choose a sequence s.t. , and then we get , so , meaning that , and we can see that, conversely, all pairs satisfy the equation.

Assume now one of the numbers is an integer. We quickly find the other one to be an integer too, so this is another type of solution: .

Finally, the last case: the numbers are rational but not integral. Let , where , and . By making , and then , we find . We can use the relation . We can find s.t. , so . At the same time, we can show in exactly the same way that , so .

Combining everything, the solutions are either of the form with being any real number, or , or .

Determine the smallest integer for which one can choose four different numbers and from any distinct integers such that is divisible by .
orl
view topic
Click for solution
I think it should be .

Let's work , so when I say distinct, for example, I mean distinct . If we look at systems consisting of distinct numbers, then we see that suffice, because they form pairs, so there must be two pairs with the same sum, and two such pairs cannot share one of the members. If a number appears more than once, then no other number can appear more than once, and a certain number cannot appear more than three times, so the number we're looking for is at most (in the case ). If we find a counterexample for , we will have shown that the answer is . Here are numbers for which distinct: . This shows that the answer is .

Standard Cauchy induction works just fine. We first prove it for two numbers: It takes the form . After expanding everything, this reduces to , which is true by AM-GM .

The next step is proving it for . This is done easily by induction: we add two inequalities with variables each, and then apply the inequality for two variables to get the result .

After this, we prove that . Assuming the inequality is true for variables, take . We get . This proves the inequality for variables .

complete the induction.

Combinatorics
1

2
Let be an integer greater than 2. A positive integer is said to be attainable if it is 1 or can be obtained from 1 by a sequence of operations with the following properties:

1.) The first operation is either addition or multiplication.

2.) Thereafter, additions and multiplications are used alternately.

3.) In each addition, one can choose independently whether to add 2 or

4.) In each multiplication, one can choose independently whether to multiply by 2 or by .

A positive integer which cannot be so obtained is said to be unattainable.


a.) Prove that if , there are infinitely many unattainable positive integers.

b.) Prove that if , all positive integers except 7 are attainable.
orl
view topic
3
Cards numbered 1 to 9 are arranged at random in a row. In a move, one may choose any block of consecutive cards whose numbers are in ascending or descending order, and switch the block around. For example, 9 1 may be changed to . Prove that in at most 12 moves, one can arrange the 9 cards so that their numbers are in ascending or descending order.
orl
view topic
4
Let , where . A subset of is said to be split by an arrangement of the elements of if an element not in occurs in the arrangement somewhere between two elements of . For example, 13542 splits but not . Prove that for any subsets of , each containing at least 2 and at most elements, there is an arrangement of the elements of which splits all of them.

5
In a contest, there are candidates and judges, where is an odd integer. Each candidate is evaluated by each judge as either pass or fail. Suppose that each pair of judges agrees on at most candidates. Prove that
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Apparently, I have the same proof as the one on Kalva..

We count the cases when two judges agree on the result of a certain contestant. Let this number be . On the one hand, we have . On the other hand, if we show that , we're done.

Consider the whole thing a -matrix having the judges as rows and the contestants as columns, and having is judge fails contestant and otherwise. It suffices to show now that for each of the columns there are at least pairs of equal numbers.

Assume on a column there are s and s with . In this case the number of matching pairs on this column is , which, knowing that is constant, is minimal when is minimal (i.e. when are as close to each other as possible), and this happens when . If we compute the number of matching pairs on this column in this particular case, we get precisely , so this is the minimal value. That is, on every column the number of matching pairs is . Thus, , Q.E.D.

view topic
6
Ten points are marked in the plane so that no three of them lie on a line. Each pair of points is connected with a segment. Each of these segments is painted with one of colors, in such a way that for any of the ten points, there are segments each joining two of them and no two being painted with the same color. Determine all integers , , for which this is possible.
orl
view topic
7
A solitaire game is played on an rectangular board, using markers which are white on one side and black on the other. Initially, each square of the board contains a marker with its white side up, except for one corner square, which contains a marker with its black side up. In each move, one may take away one marker with its black side up, but must then turn over all markers which are in squares having an edge in common with the square of the removed marker. Determine all pairs of positive integers such that all markers can be removed from the board.
orl

Click for solution
I think I got this... hopefully...

We find the solutions (1, 1), (27, 3), and (16, 2), and we claim that no others exist.

First of all, a and b must have the same ratios of prime factors, so one must divide the other. Note also that if b = xa, x > 1, then



Since x > 1, . If x = 2, then . Then we can show easily by induction that if x > 2, .

We now deal with the case .

If , gives us the solution (1, 1).

Let .





Note that . Let .





Now test cases m = 1, 2, 3, 4.

It turns out that m = 3, b = 3 works, giving us the solution (27, 3), and m = 4, b = 2 works, giving us the solution (16, 2). If m = 5, since , we have . From there on, it is easy to see by induction that , so no other solutions exist.

6
A finite number of coins are placed on an infinite row of squares. A sequence of moves is performed as follows: at each stage a square containing more than one coin is chosen. The sequence terminates if at some point there is at most one coin on each square. Given some initial configuration, show that any legal sequence of moves will terminate after the same number of steps and with the same final configuration.

Click for solution
Let's prove that only works. Obviously, is Ok, since we can take to be a square and all the 's equal to one third of the area of a triangle formed by three of its vertices. Since if we have such points we also have , all we need to do is prove that is impossible.

First notice that if is a convex quadrilateral, then and if lies inside , then . I'll use these without mentioning it from now on.

Case 1 is a convex pentagon

In this case is the same for all (the indices are modulo ), which, in turn, implies that all the are equal. This is impossible, since clearly implies .

Case 2 lies inside the convex quadrilateral

Suppose furthermore that lies inside the triangles , and outside the other two formed by the vertices . We then get , which means that . We also have . This is impossible, since it would mean that lies on the parallel to .

Case 3 lie inside

We get , so the areas of the following pairs of triangles are equal: . This means that is parallel to both and , which is, of course, absurd.

nntrkien
view topic
Click for solution
Consider the polynomial , the -th factor refering to whether is present in the set or not.

Then the monomial will refer to the set having elements and sum of elements , so we need to compute the sum of coefficients of of to find the answer.

To do this, we need to compute the sum of coefficients and substract 2, since there are two terms for :.

To compute the sum of coefficients of we use Multisection formula that says us that it equals

( is th root of unity).

Now if is not , (every will be written twice as ). This equals ( is the polynomial with roots ). Since there are choices for , choices for we get .

Finally, if , . To evaluate , note that it equals times the coefficients of in the polynomial by the same multisection formula, so it equals .

So our total sum is .
Substracting 2 we get the desired answer.
iura

Combinatorics
1
Two players play alternately on a board. The first player always enters a into an empty square and the second player always enters a into an empty square. When the board is full, the sum of the numbers in each of the nine squares is calculated and the first player's score is the largest such sum. What is the largest score the first player can make, regardless of the responses of the second player?
Fermat -Euler
view topic
2
In a certain city, age is reckoned in terms of real numbers rather than integers. Every two citizens and either know each other or do not know each other. Moreover, if they do not, then there exists a chain of citizens for some integer such that and know each other. In a census, all male citizens declare their ages, and there is at least one male citizen. Each female citizen provides only the information that her age is the average of the ages of all the citizens she knows. Prove that this is enough to determine uniquely the ages of all the female citizens.
orl
view topic
3
Peter has three accounts in a bank, each with an integral number of dollars. He is only allowed to transfer money from one account to another so that the amount of money in the latter is doubled. Prove that Peter can always transfer all his money into two accounts. Can Peter always transfer all his money into one account?
Fermat -Euler
view topic
4
There are cells in a row labeled from to and cards labeled from to . The cards are arbitrarily placed in the cells, one per cell. The objective is to get card into cell for each . The allowed move is to find the smallest such that cell has a card with a label , pick up that card, slide the cards in cells , , ... , one cell to the left and to place card in cell . Show that at most moves are required to get every card into the correct cell and that there is a unique starting position which requires moves. [For example, if and the initial position is 210, then we get 102, then 012, a total of 2 moves.]
Pascual2005
view topic

b.) Show that if it cannot terminate.

7
Let , , , be four points in the plane, with and on the same side of the line , such that and . Find the ratio

and prove that the circumcircles of the triangles and are orthogonal. (Intersecting circles are said to be orthogonal if at either common point their tangents are perpendicuar. Thus, proving that the circumcircles of the triangles and are orthogonal is equivalent to proving that the tangents to the circumcircles of the triangles and at the point are perpendicular.)

Note: Graph-Definition. A graph consists of a set of points, called vertices, together with a set of edges joining certain pairs of distinct vertices. Each pair of vertices belongs to at most one edge. The graph is connected if for each pair of distinct vertices there is some sequence of vertices such that each pair is joined by an edge of .

30

1
The integer can be written as a sum of two consecutive integers: Moreover, it can be written as a sum of (more than one) consecutive positive integers in exactly two ways: Is there an integer that can be written as a sum of consecutive integers and that can be written as a sum of (more than one) consecutive positive integers in exactly ways?

2
Given countries with three representatives each, committees are called a cycle if

(i) each committee has members, one from each country;
(ii) no two committees have the same membership;
(iii) for , committee and committee have no member in common, where denotes
(iv) if then committees and have at least one member in common.

Is it possible to have a cycle of 1990 committees with 11 countries?
orl
view topic
3
Let and consider a set of distinct points on a circle. Suppose that exactly of these points are to be colored black. 13
An eccentric mathematician has a ladder with rungs that he always ascends and descends in the following way: When he ascends, each step he takes covers rungs of the ladder, and when he descends, each step he takes covers rungs of the ladder, where and are fixed positive integers. 14
In the coordinate plane a rectangle with vertices is given where both and are odd integers. The rectangle is partitioned into triangles in such a way that

(i) each triangle in the partition has at least one side (to be called a “good” side) that lies on a line of the form or where and are integers, and the altitude on this side has length 1;

(ii) each “bad” side (i.e., a side of any triangle in the partition that is not a “good” one) is a common side of two triangles in the partition.

Prove that there exist at least two triangles in the partition each of which has two good sides.

Click for solution
It suffices to construct such a function satisfying (this implies ) and .

All we need to do is define s.t. whenever for some , where is the sequence of primes, and then extend it to the rest of so that holds. Then it's clear that will automatically hold.

2
Ali Barber, the carpet merchant, has a rectangular piece of carpet whose dimensions are unknown. Unfortunately, his tape measure is broken and he has no other measuring instruments. However, he finds that if he lays it flat on the floor of either of his storerooms, then each corner of the carpet touches a different wall of that room. If the two rooms have dimensions of 38 feet by 55 feet and 50 feet by 55 feet, what are the carpet dimensions?
orl
view topic
3
Ali Barber, the carpet merchant, has a rectangular piece of carpet whose dimensions are unknown. Unfortunately, his tape measure is broken and he has no other measuring instruments. However, he finds that if he lays it flat on the floor of either of his storerooms, then each corner of the carpet touches a different wall of that room. He knows that the sides of the carpet are integral numbers of feet and that his two storerooms have the same (unknown) length, but widths of 38 feet and 50 feet respectively. What are the carpet dimensions?

(ii) the chain of teams on the list are in rank order.

10
Three persons , are playing the following game:

A -element subset of the set is randomly chosen, with an equal probability of each choice, where is a fixed positive integer less than or equal to . The winner is or , respectively, if the sum of the chosen numbers leaves a remainder of , or when divided by .

For what values of is this game a fair one? (A game is fair if the three outcomes are equally probable.)

VNew Topic kLocked
1981 IMO Shortlist IMO Shortlist 1981
IMO Shortlist 1981
3
VNew Topic kLocked
IMO Shortlist 1981
1
a.) For which is there a set of consecutive positive integers such that the largest number in the set is a divisor of the least common multiple of the remaining numbers?

b.) For which is there exactly one set having this property?
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Let be the largest element of the set. Then divides the least common multiple of the other elements of the set iff the set has cardinality of at least , since for any of the , we must go down at least to to obtain another multiple of . In particular, there is no set of cardinality satisfying our conditions, because each number larger than or equal to must be divisible by a number that is larger than two and is a power of a prime.

For , we may let , since all the must clearly be less than and this product must also be larger than if is at least . For , we may also let , for the same reasons. However, for , this does not work, and indeed no set works other than . To prove this, we simply note that for any integer not equal to and larger than must have some power-of-a-prime factor larger than .

Q.E.D.
Boy Soprano II

16

Amir Hossein
view topic
17
Three circles of equal radius have a common point and lie inside a given triangle. Each circle touches a pair of sides of the triangle. Prove that the incenter and the circumcenter of the triangle are collinear with the point .
orl
view topic
Click for solution
Let A, B, C be the centers of the 3 congruent circles (A), (B), (C) intersecting at the point O. Since the point O is equidistant from the centers A, B, C, it is the circumcenter of the triangle . Let a, b, c be the common external tangents of the circle pairs (B), (C); (C), (A); (A), (B), neither of them intersecting the remaining circle and let the lines a, b, c intersect at points , forming a triangle . Let O' be the circumcenter of this new triangle. Since the common external tangent of 2 congruent circles is parallel to their center line, . Thus the triangles are centrally similar, having the corresponding sides parallel. The lines A'A, B'B, C'C connecting the corresponding vertices of the 2 triangles meet at their homothety center. But the lines A'A, B'B, C'C are the bisectors of the angles (and also of the angles ), hence, the homothety center is the common incenter I of the triangles . The circumcenters O', O are the corresponding points of these 2 centrally similar triangles, hence, the line O'O also passes through the homothety center I.
yetti
view topic
18
Several equal spherical planets are given in outer space. On the surface of each planet there is a set of points that is invisible from any of the remaining planets. Prove that the sum of the areas of all these sets is equal to the area of the surface of one planet.
Amir Hossein
view topic
19
A finite set of unit circles is given in a plane such that the area of their union is . Prove that there exists a subset of mutually disjoint circles such that the area of their union is greater that
Amir Hossein

11
Ten gamblers started playing with the same amount of money. Each turn they cast (threw) five dice. At each stage the gambler who had thrown paid to each of his 9 opponents times the amount which that opponent owned at that moment. They threw and paid one after the other. At the 10th round (i.e. when each gambler has cast the five dice once), the dice showed a total of 12, and after payment it turned out that every player had exactly the same sum as he had at the beginning. Is it possible to determine the total shown by the dice at the nine former rounds ?

VNew Topic kLocked
IMO Shortlist 1979
1
Prove that in the Euclidean plane every regular polygon having an even number of sides can be dissected into lozenges. (A lozenge is a quadrilateral whose four sides are all of equal length).
Amir Hossein
view topic
2
From a bag containing 5 pairs of socks, each pair a different color, a random sample of 4 single socks is drawn. Any complete pairs in the sample are discarded and replaced by a new pair draw from the bag. The process continues until the bag is empty or there are 4 socks of different colors held outside the bag. What is the probability of the latter alternative?
Amir Hossein
view topic

Amir Hossein

In every triangle which has all sides colored there exists one red side and one blue side. Prove that all the 10 sides of the two basis are colored in the same color.

14

2
A lattice point in the plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers. Each lattice point has four neighboring points: upper, lower, left, and right. Let be a circle with radius , that does not pass through any lattice point. An interior boundary point is a lattice point lying inside the circle that has a neighboring point lying outside . Similarly, an exterior boundary point is a lattice point lying outside the circle that has a neighboring point lying inside . Prove that there are four more exterior boundary points than interior boundary points.
Amir Hossein
view topic

Let be two natural numbers. When we divide by , we the the remainder and the quotient Determine all pairs for which

15
In a finite sequence of real numbers the sum of any seven successive terms is negative and the sum of any eleven successive terms is positive. Determine the maximum number of terms in the sequence.
orl
view topic
Click for solution
This is in my Top 10 of all IMO problems. Not only because I was a competitor then, but also because I was present to the "problem solving session" organized by the hosts and I wached the Czech student Martin Chadek presenting his solution, which made the jury K.O. Here it is:

Let be the given sequence and let .
The conditions from the hypothesis can be now written as and for all .
We then have:

a contradiction. Therefore, the sequence cannot have terms.
In order to show that is the answer, just take 16 real numbers satisfying
.
We have and for . Thus we found all sequences with the given properties.

As far as I know, Martin only solved this problem and got a special prize for it

Other solutions are possible, including one using linear algebra. I'll post them if anyone is interested.
enescu

1
There are six ports on a lake. Is it possible to organize a series of routes satisfying the following conditions ?
(i) Every route includes exactly three ports;
(ii) No two routes contain the same three ports;
(iii) The series offers exactly two routes to each tourist who desires to visit two different arbitrary ports.

1
Three players and play a game with three cards and on each of these cards it is written a positive integer, all numbers are different. A game consists of shuffling the cards, giving each player a card and each player is attributed a number of points equal to the number written on the card and then they give the cards back. After a number of games we find out that A has points, has points and has points. We also know that in the last game B had the card with the biggest number. Who had in the first game the card with the second value (this means the middle card concerning its value).

it's an easy check to show that no terms can be , since sequence has a short period...

10

view topic
11
We consider the division of a chess board in p disjoint rectangles which satisfy the conditions:

a) every rectangle is formed from a number of full squares (not partial) from the 64 and the number of white squares is equal to the number of black squares.

b) the numbers of white squares from rectangles satisfy Find the greatest value of for which there exists such a division and then for that value of all the sequences for which we can have such a division.


Moderator says: see http://www.artofproblemsolving.com/Forum/viewtopic.php?f=41&t=58591
Amir Hossein
view topic
12
In a certain language words are formed using an alphabet of three letters. Some words of two or more letters are not allowed, and any two such distinct words are of different lengths. Prove that one can form a word of arbitrary length that does not contain any non-allowed word.
Amir Hossein

12
Consider the two square matrices


with entries and . The following operations will be called elementary:

(1) Changing signs of all numbers in one row;

(2) Changing signs of all numbers in one column;

(3) Interchanging two rows (two rows exchange their positions);

(4) Interchanging two columns.

Prove that the matrix cannot be obtained from the matrix using these operations.

14
A soldier needs to check if there are any mines in the interior or on the sides of an equilateral triangle His detector can detect a mine at a maximum distance equal to half the height of the triangle. The soldier leaves from one of the vertices of the triangle. Which is the minimum distance that he needs to traverse so that at the end of it he is sure that he completed successfully his mission?

view topic
Click for solution
Consider the function

where .
If is an approximation to a root of this function, then is next approximation to the root of this function obtained by using the Newton-Raphson method. So a solution of the system of equations corresponds to a failure of the Newton-Raphson method to find a root of this function, producing instead a cycle of length .

We have while perfect cubes are always congruent to 0, 1 or 8 (mod 9).

So, there are no solutions.

Solution by grobber:

Assume such a number exists.

We have , so . Let . We then get , but cannot be divisible by . We have a contradiction, so no such exists.

6
In making Euclidean constructions in geometry it is permitted to use a ruler and a pair of compasses. In the constructions considered in this question no compasses are permitted, but the ruler is assumed to have two parallel edges, which can be used for constructing two parallel lines through two given points whose distance is at least equal to the breadth of the rule. Then the distance between the parallel lines is equal to the breadth of the ruler. Carry through the following constructions with such a ruler. Construct:

a) The bisector of a given angle.
b) The midpoint of a given rectilinear line segment.
c) The center of a circle through three given non-collinear
points.
d) A line through a given point parallel to a given line.
darij grinberg

Find the angle between the upper base and the light ray at the moment when the light ray entered the prism, and the length of the way of the light ray in the interior of the prism.

20

Consider the convex polyhedron whose vertices are the vertices of the rectangles.

a.) What is the volume of this polyhedron ?

b.) Can this polyhedron turn out to be a regular polyhedron ? If yes, what is the condition for this polyhedron to be regular ?

23

(b) Prove that if all the faces are right triangles, then the volume of the tetrahedron equals one -sixth the product of the three smallest edges not belonging to the same face.

(2) The red segments form a closed way passing through all given points. (Similarly for the blue segments.)

b.) Give a plan how to paint the segments either red or blue in order to have the condition (no triangle with equally colored sides) satisfied.
